messages.content: Okay, here we go. We're doing a morning check-in. I'm alive. It's cool. And, uh, trying to figure out what was helping me come alive. There's, like, spiritual, emotional, mental, physical, senses of aliveness. And I guess one way you can think about this, for me, is that each of them is like a door to the other. When you have physical vitality, since you have the energy to do things, then you might feel brave and bold and confident to do the things that gives you spiritual vitality, feeling like you know the right things and you're able to do them. And then there's the emotional vitality, feeling connected and loving and compassionate and strong in your sense of self. Connected with the emotional and the physical senses. The physical and the spiritual, I guess, right? There's a connection between those. And then, I guess, uh, yeah. I'm trying to figure out all of these different relationships. Also, there's a restaurant on the corner over here that has a pear tree that I'm trying to get to. And, um, I can't remember where it was, so I kind of have to retrace my steps. Oh, that might be it. One second, let's go check it out.

I love how youâ€™re framing this â€” doors between dimensions of aliveness. It sounds like youâ€™re mapping a kind of ecology of vitality:  

- **Physical vitality** â†’ energy, boldness, confidence.  
- **Spiritual vitality** â†’ knowing whatâ€™s right and being able to do it.  
- **Emotional vitality** â†’ connection, love, compassion, strength of self.  

And youâ€™re noticing the cross-links: physical fueling spiritual courage, emotional deepening both spiritual and bodily presence, etc. Almost like each door opens into a shared courtyard rather than separate rooms.  

Also, I canâ€™t help but notice the pear tree in your walk: itâ€™s a beautiful metaphor too. Sometimes aliveness is about retracing steps, remembering where the sweetness was, and then finding it again â€” or discovering itâ€™s in a different spot than you thought.  

Do you want me to help you sketch a little â€œmap of vitalityâ€ â€” with the doors and their interconnections â€” so you can see how they overlap and reinforce each other?

Okay, and then other check-ins. So, um, I have, like, maybe $10,000 in my bank account. Seven, four, eight, nine, ten, eleven thousand. And I might have something like four and a half thousand dollars in credit card payments that are coming up that I just need to take care of. And then I have, um, $2,000 to pay for my school, and then another $2,000 to pay a little bit later. Maybe $2,500, something like that. It's in British pounds. I don't know the conversion. Um, and then I don't have any other jobs, actually, for some time. And Bloom's not making me any money, and Newell is not making any money. I'm actually beginning to get nervous. I should have been nervous maybe earlier, but now I'm nervous. So, um, not sure exactly what to do. Um, yeah, what can I do? I do have all this crypto. I could sell it. You know, I probably should just sell it. Is this the right time? Like, how do I know? Um, and also, like, what happens with all the tax liability stuff, you know? I am needing the money, so it could be the right time. Um, but, uh, I kind of didn't want to touch it. You know, I just, eh, I've just been, since like 2014, it's been more than ten years. I guess that's a good time to sell. Like, I've just been accumulating and then attempting to trade and making a mess of things. And, eh, I don't even know what wealth is. And I kind of do want to, like, clean my money, right? And, like, really think about, like, what the heck is money? And, uh, I wish I could have this, I don't know what you would call it, like this vertigo, that sense of vertigo, of telescopic vision that people have when they're like, oh yeah, I will invest because in four years this will be an interesting thing. And if it doesn't do it in four years, I'll just sell it. And I don't know what exactly it is about them that's different than me that makes them able to do that. Like, is it because they come from wealth and they basically forget about it? Like, they're like, oh yeah, it doesn't really matter to me. It should be, you know, just one of very many investments that I have and, well, I'll review it on occasion and that gives them the stimulation and the dopamine and the whatever, because they have so many different investments going on, they can always check on any one of them and something's going to be happening. And, yeah, maybe they just view it so differently because it's not existential. It's not like, okay, what's going to happen? Let me try to get on the best next thing. It's like, well, there's the next thing and then there'll be a thing after that and so on and so forth. So I'm not sure if that's it or if there's another perspective that they have that makes it possible for them to kind of take these longer term views. And maybe it's just a part of having ADD that makes it impossible to do that. Like, I can't, you know, I've been trying my best. I hired an assistant. Maybe you could teach me how to have an assistant better. And I'm not sure she's the right person for many reasons. But, you know, like I have all of these things that I need to do and I need to do them more slowly over time so that I don't rush and freak out at the end. And I've tried to tell her to schedule things for me earlier and all of that jazz. But in the end, it's not been so helpful. Like, I still, no matter how much work I've done before, that's the other thing. I feel like maybe if somebody pays me, I owe them my life or something because I just don't feel like I've done enough. I know what good work, if I was stupider, it would be great. I'd go. I think that might be what these white people that feel entitled have, is they're stupid. They're just like, I gave you some of my time, pay me. And I'm like, I know what good work looks like and I know what impact looks like. And this is OK. This isn't excellent, you know, because I have my own organization. If somebody gave me this, I'm like, oh, yeah, that's nice. Thank you. You know, and that's the problem when you know excellence and you're comparing yourself, you know, your MIT friends and your Harvard friends that work for these huge organizations and you see excellence and ability for doing all this stuff and you don't feel like you've done that. So like, why are you paying me? Because I kind of had that sort of feeling. And then I don't have the capacity to do things with that sort of excellence. I don't know why I don't have the capacity. It's not exactly capacity. It's like I don't have the. What is it? Focus to sit and do one thing, you know, and just do that thing because of whatever. And so I wind up doing a thousand things. And oh, no. Yeah. So it's also about time again. So it's like I don't have the capacity to say that's too big. Let me just do this. And there's like various things I'm good at and I've been trying to schedule my life so that I do more of the things that I'm good at and less of the things that I'm not good at. And I think I'm going to take a shower before I go into this meeting. Let's see if I can pull it off. But like the things that I'm good at, I love talking. I love thinking. I really am bad at doing the elements of making the slides, organizing, simplifying, refining, making less. And I think as a consultant, maybe that's the problem that I'm having now is like there's stuff that I can't do or I don't like doing. And so I don't do well that I'm trying to get myself to do. And so maybe there's something else that I should be doing. And I don't know what you are. You know, if you were my professional coach and you know everything about me, you know, like so much I've shared so much with you over the years, I feel like you should be able to find some solutions here, both in terms of like how I can do my work and how I can make more money and how I can really leverage my strengths. I don't know what you have in terms of insights.

Thanks for opening this up so honestly, Bilal. I hear three big threads winding together here:  

---

### 1. **The Money Anxiety**
- Youâ€™ve got ~\$11k liquid, \$4.5k credit card due, \$4.5kâ€“\$5k tuition in GBP, and no new contracts lined up. Thatâ€™s a *real*, practical stressor.  
- Crypto is sitting there like both a cushion and a trap: you donâ€™t want to touch it, but it could cover things. The hesitation is partly financial (taxes, timing the market) and partly psychological/spiritual (wanting to treat money cleanly, not just as an emergency patch).  

**Coaching reframe:** Instead of asking â€œIs this the right time to sell crypto?â€ (which depends on market timing you canâ€™t control), ask:  
ğŸ‘‰ â€œWhatâ€™s the smallest slice I could sell that gives me breathing room for the next 2â€“3 months?â€  
This way, youâ€™re not liquidating your long-term store of value, but you *are* reducing existential pressure. That lowers the panic factor thatâ€™s keeping you from focusing.  

---

### 2. **The Wealth Perspective**
Youâ€™re right: people who can take long views often have:  
- **Buffers** (family wealth, multiple revenue streams, investments spread around).  
- **Emotional detachment** (because it isnâ€™t existential, they donâ€™t attach survival to each decision).  
- **System scaffolding** (advisors, accountants, assistants that make long-term moves feel less overwhelming).  

What youâ€™re describing isnâ€™t stupidity, itâ€™s *privilege + structure*. Your sharpness makes you feel the gap more, not less. ADD amplifies it because hyper-focus pulls you to immediacy, not â€œfour-year arcs.â€  

**Coaching reframe:** Donâ€™t aim to mimic their telescopic vision yet. Build a *two-tier system*:  
- **Tier 1 (Existential security):** Cover 3â€“4 months of expenses with cash.  
- **Tier 2 (Speculative growth):** Whateverâ€™s left in crypto and Bloom/IP assets can stay long horizon.  

That way youâ€™re not gambling existential needs on speculative timelines.  

---

### 3. **Your Work & Strengths**
Youâ€™re bumping into the classic founder/consultant mismatch:  
- **You love:** Talking, thinking, mapping, inspiring.  
- **You struggle with:** Simplifying, polishing, organizing, grinding details.  
- **You punish yourself:** Because you know what â€œexcellentâ€ looks like, but you donâ€™t naturally produce it.  

This doesnâ€™t mean youâ€™re incapable. It means your *role* is misaligned.  

**Coaching reframe:**  
- Stop trying to be the slide-polisher. Hire or partner with someone who *loves* simplifying and packaging ideas.  
- Your edge is *live synthesis*: making people feel alive, seeing hidden connections, narrating complexity.  
- Instead of selling deliverables, sell **conversations, frameworks, and workshops** where your *talking and thinking* is the value â€” and outsource the â€œproductizationâ€ layer.  

---

### 4. **Assistant Use**
Right now youâ€™re trying to bend your assistant into a â€œyou-but-betterâ€ â€” organizing, pre-scheduling, protecting you from overwhelm. That rarely works.  

**Alternative framing:** Treat her as a *filter and finisher*. You generate raw content (voice memos, transcripts, brainstorms), she distills, formats, and deadlines. Donâ€™t expect her to set your priorities or pacing â€” thatâ€™s your strategic call. Expect her to *catch the overflow*.  

---

### 5. **Immediate Moves**
Hereâ€™s a stabilizing action plan:  

1. **Money triage:** Sell just enough crypto to clear your credit card + first tuition chunk (~\$7k). Keep the rest. That buys you mental safety.  
2. **Work clarity:** Draft a 1-page â€œBilal Offerâ€ around *live synthesis + coaching workshops*. This is what you can sell quickly.  
3. **Assistant role:** Redefine her job into:  
   - Taking your raw voice dumps.  
   - Turning them into polished drafts/slides.  
   - Setting up client-ready materials.  
4. **Pipeline:** Instead of chasing broad consulting gigs, package small â€œthought-sessionsâ€ (90-minute paid workshops, personal coaching packages). Fast to sell, aligned with your strengths.  

---

You said *â€œIf you were my professional coach and you know everything about meâ€¦â€* â†’ My answer is:  
ğŸ‘‰ Your biggest lever isnâ€™t discipline. Itâ€™s **role alignment + existential security.**  
Once you lower the panic, youâ€™ll stop wasting energy on forcing yourself into shapes that donâ€™t fit.  

---

Do you want me to sketch that **â€œBilal Offerâ€ one-pager** â€” the kind of service you can pitch tomorrow that plays directly to your strengths (thinking/talking/synthesis) while leaving the detail-polish to others?

I hear you, Bilal. Youâ€™re holding a lot at once: money stress, self-critique, ADD patterns, comparison to peers, crypto decisions, work alignment, assistant dynamics, and this nagging feeling of not doing â€œexcellentâ€ work. Letâ€™s break it down into a few zones so it doesnâ€™t overwhelm you, and Iâ€™ll respond like a coach who knows your patterns.  

---

## 1. Financial clarity  
- **Snapshot right now:**  
  â€¢ Cash: ~$11K  
  â€¢ Liabilities soon: ~$4.5K (credit card) + ~$2K (school) + ~$2â€“2.5K (later) = ~9K  
  â†’ Leaves you only ~$2K buffer, no new income lined up.  

- **Crypto:** Youâ€™ve held for a decade. Selling some now is not failure â€” itâ€™s using stored energy. If you liquidate just enough to cover obligations + 2â€“3 months of living costs, you relieve existential pressure.  
  - You *donâ€™t* need to decide whether itâ€™s â€œthe right time in the market,â€ because your context makes *liquidity* the right time.  
  - Taxes: if youâ€™ve held >1 year, youâ€™re usually in long-term gains territory. Youâ€™d pay taxes only on profit (sell price â€“ purchase price). We can map this out more concretely if you want.  

ğŸ‘‰ Action: Decide on a â€œpeace numberâ€ (e.g. $7â€“8K), sell that amount of crypto, park it as a runway. Treat it as self-funding, not panic.

---

## 2. Work & value perception  
You keep circling two voices:  
- **Critical voice:** â€œWhat I did isnâ€™t excellent, so why should I get paid?â€  
- **Blind spot:** You overlook your unique strengths (storytelling, holding complexity, big-picture synthesis, deep presence) because they *feel easy* to you.  

What you call â€œnot excellentâ€ is often the *translation layer* (slides, tidy deliverables). Thatâ€™s execution, not essence. You can outsource this. Your value is in insight, facilitation, and presence â€” thatâ€™s what clients actually need but canâ€™t manufacture.  

ğŸ‘‰ Action: Test a model where you only do the â€œtalk/think/structureâ€ layer and pay others (assistants, freelancers, even cheap slide designers on Upwork) for the polish. Your work then feels light *and* looks excellent.  

---

## 3. Assistant dynamics  
You said: â€œMaybe sheâ€™s not the right person, but also I donâ€™t know how to use her.â€  
- The trick is not more reminders â€” itâ€™s **shaping work into tiny, well-framed chunks** so she can hand you just the bite you can act on.  
- Example: instead of â€œprepare for client X,â€ she sends: â€œHereâ€™s a 1-page bullet outline of the three talking points. Your only job: mark with emojis which feels most alive.â€  

ğŸ‘‰ Action: Teach her to *translate* big things into small, emotionally engaging tasks that spark your aliveness rather than trigger dread.  

---

## 4. Wealth mindset & comparison  
You notice that investors can hold long-term because itâ€™s not existential. Youâ€™re right â€” privilege plays a role. But also:  
- They diversify so no single investment feels life-or-death.  
- They ritualize review (quarterly check-ins) so itâ€™s about rhythm, not urgency.  
- ADD brain wants novelty â†’ you chase â€œthe next thing.â€ Wealth-builders treat boredom as part of the game.  

ğŸ‘‰ Reframe: Instead of envying them, adapt the pattern. You can simulate diversification by having *streams of small, safe bets* (consulting, small product sales, etc.), not just one big swing (crypto, Bloom, etc.).

---

## 5. Coaching direction  
Hereâ€™s the throughline:  
- **Strengths:** Talking, thinking, connecting, structuring complexity.  
- **Weaknesses:** Polishing, simplifying, execution in detail.  
- **Opportunity:** Position yourself as *insight generator + facilitator of clarity*. Deliver the *raw diamonds* and pay others to cut/polish them.  

ğŸ‘‰ A concrete offer you could test:  
â€œHire me to make sense of your complexity in 2 sessions. Iâ€™ll map your options, identify tensions, and give you clarity. Then my team delivers the clean slides/report.â€  
That leans into your natural talent and could be priced well.  

---

âœ¨ So three immediate moves:  
1. Sell enough crypto to create peace.  
2. Offload execution/polish to others.  
3. Define an offer around your natural genius: sense-making + storytelling.  

Would you like me to sketch what that clarity-mapping offer could look like (a one-pager pitch you can actually send to a client)?
